Spacex, NASA, Dragon, Starship, Moon (and Martin?)


WOW! People delivered to orbit in a vehicle that has an interior style very (very) close to the visual appearance of a Hollywood Sci-Fi set!

Filmmakers may no longer have the luxury of making spacecraft interiors out of repurposed construction materials and odd shaped wood, foam and plastic bits all painted white.

May need to go back to clean ‘Space Oddessy’ style in order to maintain a look and feel beyond what may now be deemed ‘contemporary’.

Makes ISS interior look a bit ‘dated’ in comparison ( but still impressively scientific and ‘spacey’ ).

Can’t wait to see what Spacex will have in store for their ‘Starship’ interior.

Should have plenty of room for Martin (composer, performer, Wintergatan channel) and whatever futuristic looking instrument(s) he might bring along if he is chosen to go to the moon.

The world wide team of Wintergatan engineers and fabricators should be able to come up with something small(ish) , lightweight, and appropriately ‘spacey’ for zero gravity composing and performance with a live backdrop of moon, earth and stars.

(‘Course, a guy in a Spacex suit and helmet floating around whilst playing a saw would be kinda cool too!)

Stay well....

PS: Stars probably don’t show up well in images from space craft so I guess Martin would have to bring a few of his own, eh?

Dude i love watching your videos on space x....its very rare that u get too see science play out before your eyes, the trial and error and the crashes and explosions with the successes. It got me thinking though, the space x technology is very new, with being able to land and re-use rockets, but isnt rocket technology in itself an old technology? Now theyre looking at forms of electro magnetic propulsion, the kind of tech that will be used in rail guns to make the cost of launching into space cheaper. Maybe its that kind of tecnology they should be looking at because that represents another jump in current technology and therefore presents an oppertunity to under cut space x at some point in the future by a different company?

Fantastic, historic, mission but it seems NASA has still learned NOTHING about the importance of making space travel exciting for the taxpaying viewers! I understand that everything has to be done by pre-written procedures but can those procedures not be written with the tiniest consideration for viewers? TWENTY MINUTES between finally getting the last hatch open and the astronauts entering the ISS was just ridiculous. What could they possibly have had to do that they couldn't go back in and do later? They'd been docked for over an hour by then. Go back and clean the toilet after we've all switched off!
"TV doesn't matter" people might say, but boring TV is a major reason why Apollo got cancelled.

I watched the STS-135 launch from Titusville (specifically from the Shiloh's Steak and Seafood parking lot), and was somewhat disappointed by the sound level, between being three times as far away and the wind being behind me at the time. That said, it's still a sound you'll never forget in your life.

I promised myself after Challenger that I'd see a Shuttle launch in person before the end of the program, and I may have cut it close, but I made it. I've promised myself that I'll be down at the Cape to see something else big launch at least once more in my life; that's a promise I intend to keep. And THIS time, I'll make arrangements early enough to get Apollo-Saturn Center tickets for the launch...

Got a question: The next big thing is the development of the star ship is the cargo version for NASA's return to the Moon. Here's the question with a depth of ? regolith on the surface making it difficult to land and take off using the aft engines why not use a band of super draco thrusters (73,000 newtons (16,400 lbf) of thrust) in the first ring below the nose cone for take off and landing? Very low gravity should make it possible .  Though the two are vastly different  the engine used to land on the moon had 24.5 kN (5,500 lbf) of thrust, that shouldn't be hard to scale up. That configuration may also be used in any landing where a non prepared surface exist, Mars for example.

Stars above, Earth below
soaring into dreams well dreamt
yet by minds a hundred years ago,
with a quest for the unknown,
the branded unachievable,
they’re off to conquer a crimson throne.
To go beyond, onwards, and onwards
like Mother’s child ready to fly,
unstopable, upwards, and upwards,
and with the thunder of a lion’s roar,
in a moment for all else to linger,
our hearts shake to their very core.
And Mothers, Fathers, Children, they yell:
Here’s to humanity, here’s to new worlds,
go NASA, go SpaceX, godspeed, farewell!
Stars above, and Earth below,
two souls, lifting off to go the distance,
soaring into the afterglow.

When I watched Apollo 11 lifting off on its way to the moon I was in awe at the level of technology used to get them there. Watching the SpaceX rocket lift off on its way to the ISS and then see the first stage booster return and land on the deck of a ship was just amazing, incredible, it seemed almost impossible, and the the Dragon capsule is so spacious compared to Apollo. Technology is increasing at an exponential rate and sending people to Mars doesn’t sound so far fetched anymore.

Touch screens and buttons.....

The older spacecraft had certain switches that had red covers that kept them from being triggered accidentally.

How do they keep similar things from happening as the astronauts brush by their touch screens and control panels while moving about in zero g?

I watched SO much streaming of this launch, Wed and today, that it took me back to ALL the manned missions in my life, which was all of them.  The firsts were the best (Alan Shepherd (I was 6yrs), John Glenn, Moon, Shuttle, Falcon9/"Endeavor" (what Doug and Bob named their Dragon)).  It's good to be back in space on our own, with more to come!  Nice that we could build bonds with Roscos but limited just a ride, not a program. YAY and glad Doug and Bob are A-OK, so far. I was watching the launch from my front porch from 130 Miles/210KM away in Northeast Florida and am always in awe in seeing a launch and my first was a shuttle launch and that was truly special. Although I also saw the last Shuttle launch this way and could see it all the way up which I think is because of it having 2 booster which were bigger too...
But yeah if your in Northeast Florida during a launch look to the south and you might see one.
